statement.text: Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) is a fibrosing panniculitis of the lower extremity characterized by chronic inflammation, fibrosis of subcutaneous fat, and skin induration, representing CEAP class C4b and indicating significant risk of ulceration.
statement.formal: LDS â†’ CEAP_C4b; Ulceration_Risk: 40-50% at 5 years if untreated

explanation.intuition: LDS represents advanced venous disease where sustained venous hypertension has caused progressive scarring of the fat and skin in the lower leg, creating the characteristic woody, tight texture that can constrict the leg like a 'champagne bottle' or 'inverted bowling pin'.
explanation.key_insight: LDS exists in acute and chronic phases. Acute LDS presents with painful, warm, erythematous plaques mimicking cellulitis or DVT, while chronic LDS shows fibrotic induration. Recognition of acute LDS prevents unnecessary antibiotic courses and guides appropriate venous management.
explanation.technical_details: Histologically, LDS shows septal and lobular panniculitis with lipomembranous changes (microcyst formation in fat), capillary proliferation, and progressive fibrosis. The pathophysiology involves venous hypertension causing capillary leak, extravascular fibrin deposition, fat necrosis, and subsequent fibrotic replacement. The medial gaiter area is most affected due to maximum hydrostatic pressure.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Acute LDS is cellulitis requiring antibiotics. Reality: Acute LDS is sterile inflammation; distinguishing features include bilateral involvement, clear demarcation, and venous stigmata.
Misconception: LDS is reversible with treatment. Reality: Established fibrosis is permanent; treatment prevents progression and ulceration.
Misconception: LDS only occurs with obvious varicose veins. Reality: Deep venous disease and perforator incompetence can cause LDS without visible varicosities.

presentation: Acute phase: Tender, warm, erythematous indurated plaques on medial lower leg
Chronic phase: Woody, bound-down induration of the gaiter area
Inverted champagne bottle or bowling pin leg shape
Pain and tenderness, especially acute phase
Restricted ankle mobility from skin and subcutaneous tethering
differential_diagnosis: Cellulitis (usually unilateral, systemic symptoms, responds to antibiotics)
Deep vein thrombosis (calf tenderness, acute swelling)
Pretibial myxedema (thyroid disease, pretibial not gaiter)
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on appearance and location
Duplex ultrasound to document underlying venous disease
Biopsy rarely needed; shows panniculitis with lipomembranous change
MRI may show subcutaneous enhancement and thickening
treatment: Compression therapy (cornerstone - reduces edema and inflammation)
Treatment of underlying venous reflux (ablation, sclerotherapy)
Anti-inflammatory medications for acute painful episodes

definition.@value: A chronic fibrosing inflammatory condition of the subcutaneous fat and dermis of the lower leg caused by venous hypertension, characterized by induration, hyperpigmentation, and the classic 'inverted champagne bottle' deformity.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy

learning_objectives: Distinguish LDS from cellulitis and other mimics
Explain the pathophysiology of venous panniculitis
clinical_pearls: Acute LDS is often misdiagnosed as cellulitis - look for bilateral involvement and venous stigmata
The 'inverted champagne bottle' leg is pathognomonic
Compression is the cornerstone of treatment
Fibrosis is irreversible; early intervention prevents progression
40-50% of patients with LDS will develop ulcers if untreated
